content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												First of all, there is no inbetween with this game, you either hate it or love it. So before you spend that precious $1.24, let's evaluate if you will or will not love it:1. Do you like point and click games?2. Do you like heavily plot based games?3. Are you into cinematography, graphic arts, and/or innovative story telling?4. Do you value the EXPERIENCE of a game over what you can actually DO in a game?If you answered "yes" to all 4, this is definitely the game for you. This kind of game is so different and wonderfully pieced together. I cannot believe how many emotions this game made me feel in under 10 minutes. It was heart-pounding and heart-felt. DO realize though that it's more of a visual novel and therefore your actions are chosen for you, you just are simply there to enjoy the ride. Which is exactly what I did, I enjoyed the ride.AS A BONUS: you also get their first game Gravity Bone (can't find it? hit esc and click careers) which unlike this sequal allows the player to move and figure out what they have to do, which is much more interactive but still as fun as Thirty Flights of Loving.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												I'm all about experimental gaming and narrative-dedicated games, but Thirty Flights of Loving is too short and abstract to be meaningful. It attempts to play off its poor, blocky graphics as "stylized." I would be fine with paying this much money for a 15 minute game if it featured a meaningful, elaborate narrative. Sadly, it comes off as unfocused, choppy, and incoherent.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This is at its best an ~*artistic*~ walking simulator.This is at its worst a diminutive walking simulator.This was an effort by its designer (apparently) to engage in storytelling without typical narrative techniques, ie. Voiceovers, random data files, etc. Commendable, but borrowing from cinema isn't anything new. Games have borrowed from cinema repeatedly.What this game doesn't really spend much, if any, time doing is having the actual structure of the gameplay inform us of story. At one point, in his commentary, the designer explains that he used a characters acceptance of our taking an orange for ourselves to show that this was a space we belonged in. But in a game with such sparse interaction, we as players can't tell the difference between a character's acceptance of our actions, and lazy coding that failed to include consequences for our actions.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Thirty Flights of Loving is the sequel to the game Gravity Bone from 2008.It is the perfect game to play when you have a bunch of friends over. Its extreme strangeness and unique humor will leave you all utterly confused. It's not just weird and funny, though. Through its simplistic style, it is able to convey an intriguing and comprehensive story.If you aren't sure what to expect and don't want to spend $5 on something that may disappoint you, download Gravity Bone. You can download it for free from the developer's website.If you do buy it, be sure to play through a second time with the developer commentary on. It is fascinating to see how much thought went into the level design, and I have great respect for the developer, Brendon Chung.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												I did not enjoy this game. It's just a bunch of confusing rooms and poorly-animated character interactions. The environments and graphics were ugly, even if the art style is meant to be simplistic. The gameplay seems to be split into 2 stories: Thirty Flights of Loving and Gravity Bone. TFOL is just exploring various environments; there is almost no interaction by the player other than walking. Gravity Bone has more interactivity, with items to use and quests to complete, but it is still extremely linear and vague in terms of what is happening.I do give this game credit for attempting to tell a story without voice or dialogue, but it was executed terribly. Maybe I just suck at infering things, but I could not follow what sort of story this game was trying to tell.

Who knows, maybe someone other than me will understand and enjoy what they're trying to do here.(I must admit, peeling the orange was oddly satisfying.)

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I ended up enjoying it, but i can't recommend Thirty Flights of Loving, unless you carefully read about it and knows exactly what you'll get or experience. Then you can find it cool, just after you understand what it is.My first experience was disappointing.Being someone who usually enjoy art games or interactive experiences, i start it thinking about a cool, deep story-driven game, but i found me just watching disordered short scenes of a shallow and confusing story, instead of really playing something. It ended really fast, abruptly and letting me with a "wtf?!" in mind. The graphics, lights, colors and music are really cool, but it was not enough to make me enjoy.Then i try it again a few days later.Knowing what to expect, the experience was far better, and i used to enjoy it and understand it. Using the commentaries feature, i found it was a developer experience, something really personal using his experiences on gaming design and pieces he previously wanted to use in other ways.I don't read all the comments yet, and i still having to play better the Gravity Bone bonus, who seems to have more gameplay elements, but if you're ok with all that i said before, i can recommend this experience to you, it worth your time. But i'll not recommend to everybody, mostly without that explanation about what i feel in my first contact with it.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2012
												It's not quite a game, it's not quite an interactive movie. It's... I don't know what the hell it is. It's short (20-30 minutes), and it looks simple. You can't really play it, you have to experience it. The music is brilliant though. It's the kind of music that could be used in movies. I enjoyed it THAT much. The 'game' itself... not so much though. It does a decent job of telling a story but I have no idea what it's all about. It seems you have to 'play' it several times to fully understand it. Worth it ? Not for this price. Other games have way more gameplay, for the same price or lower. But, I guess it's a nice tech demo.[Rating: 57/100]

												A surprising lack of content and interactivity for a game rated so highly. It does have high points in that it's quick-cut action-style presentation is something I can't place in any other game. However, don't expect substantial meaty bits in between the quick cuts. Similarly, you'll have to contain your disbelief when the game ends in less than 15 minutes. Given just how very little game there is here and how much that contributes to an overall feeling of dissatisfaction when its over, I have to not recommend this.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I have spent 31 minutes playing this game, at least half were setting up my computer and trying to make it work. This game is... Well to put it bluntly,♥♥♥♥♥♥  A 10 minute game, where the entire "gameplay" is walk from point to point, and that's bad.  The game offers you a use item button, and a inventory system.  I found guns, I couldn't use, oranges that you can peel and eat (for no reason) and ... that's it. I can't express how low my opinion of the game, even when the game should be constricting you to a position (riding on a motorcycle, in a plane) you're able to free roam for no reason.  I'm riding on a bike and I can walk to the right or left, and yet still travel at the same speed as the bike, and then the game ends? The story is rough.  There's what feels like four scenes, but it doesn't really fit together in any interesting way.  The name of the game makes almost no sense.   And overall there's nothing good to recommend here. The only good news is if you buy this game, you can play it and get a refund in the time it takes watch a tv show with out commercials.   But honestly, there's NOTHING here. I can't believe people would recommend a 10 minute game to anyone. And btw no this isn't "art" I don't think you can hide behind that, there's games that are art, like Stanley's parable, Gone Home, and The Beginner's guide, and I can have different opinions on them.  This isn't even attempting to be art, it's a cash grab.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												What made me want to play this game is how critics say that it has great story telling. When you start playing, you find a hidden passage in the wall and a gun behind the counter. Once you go through the door, you collect more guns and ammo for them. However, they are never used since the "game" is entirely about the story. From this point on, it feels like the game is rushing through its story. Key word on the rushing. One moment, you are riding on a plane. The next, you are walking down a busy hallway. What makes this strange is that there are no transitions from one scene to another. This often makes it feel less like real story and more like a random collection of clips from several movies. Add to it that the whole thing ends in 15 minutes, and it feels more like a test program. They included another game called "Gravity Bone" that feels more like a real game, but it still does not feel like it is enough to worth buying. If you can play this on a friend's computer, do it that way. My family got it because it was part of a bundle. As a standalone product, I would not recommend buying this one.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This is actually really cool, it's rare to see games do so much with so little. With cube heads, a simple linear path, essentially no words (okay, that's a lie, I guess I mean no dialogue), and about fifteen minutes, it manages to be something of a masterclass in game storytelling, communicating at a level of effectiveness that verbose, exposition-heavy "AAA" rollercoasters would kill for.For me, the use of sharp cuts ahead in a scene, or between scenes, was worth the price of admission alone. It's a technique I've of course experienced in many many films, but I don't think I've ever seen it used in games before, and it's a wonderful way of both creating (or perhaps emulating) a certain style, and putting you in the headspace needed to make the most of each scene.Yes, it's "only" fifteen minutes long, in the same way that, I don't know, Swift's seminal essay A Modest Proposal is only a few pages, or your favourite song only lasts three minutes thirty. If you're one of the people that (bizarrely, I maintain) measures experiences by dividing cost by length, this isn't for you. And I wasn't, you know, floored; blown away in amazement. But it is quietly amazing; a significant accomplishment content to sit and do its own thing while the world shows off noisily around it. I think people with an interest in the presentation of narrative in games - beyond mere text dumps - should really check this out.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
I literally regret all the 149 cents I've spent on "this". Not because of the small amount of money I've spent. I regret I've supported, even a little, a developer like that.Look, I LOVE arthouse. I love games without traditional gameplay (visual novels or whatever they are called). I love The Path, I love Dear Easther, I love The Stanley Parable, I love The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.BUT THIS. Critics claim it's brilliant, 'cause it doesn't present you linear nor transparent storyline, so you have to decide all the plot and intrigue for yourself.I don't have problems with the plot, my problem is that those claims are lies. This "game"... Geez, I can't name it nor "game" nor "visual novel" in fact. Ok, this "thing" doesn't even trying to do something good. Like, literally, I can't see the developer trying to be good in any aspect of this... "thing".Graphics, animations, sound design etc. are not intentionally simplistic, they simply lack any art style or tech, programming is horrible. In the most horrible sense possible. That leaves you with a story... Except all those "visual novel" games I love tear their asses to present the story in most beautiful, unusual and most memorable way. And this "thing" not even trying. Supposedly intentionally, but in fact, because of untalented developer who couldn't make any idea.It's not Malevich's Black Square. It's simply a square. Not even sure it's black. It's pseudo art.In developer commentaries it was said, that the scene with floating objects was initially bug, but dev decided to make it a part of the "game". Well, the WHOLE damn "game" is like that, in fact. SOLID BUG.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10
												Thirty Flights of Loving feels like a pitch for a bigger game. Before things could get interesting, it's over.I'd like to point out right away that the game did not like my computer. The game crashed multiple times after trying to change settings, and I managed to somehow die during the first jump cut...and then crash. Setting the game's executable to Windows 98 compatibility mode and setting the resolution options as launch parameters seemed to fix it.I do quite like the art style, and the music and sound effects are excellent. It's just a shame that there's not too much of any of it.That's not to say what's there is bad. I like the general presentation of the story, for the most part. Due to the jump cuts, it can be unclear on the exact order of events that occur. You're missing parts of the story, and what's there is out of order, but piecing it together isn't ridiculously complicated. That said, I can understand why it might confuse some.As I said before, though, it feels like a pitch to raise money for a longer version of the game. I want more details on the story. What went wrong with the job they were on, and what was the job they were doing, anyway? You have to give a reason for people to care. A summary of a story never has the impact that the full story does.My feelings about Gravity Bone, the prequel to this (and which is included in this package), can be summed up in pretty much the same way, with one additional complaint: the gameplay. While Thirty Flights of Loving is mostly a walking simulator with very limited activity, Gravity Bone has a few items that you pick up and carry in your inventory. While having  interactivity is fine in a walking simulator, Gravity Bone makes the mistake of making what limited interactivity is in the game repetitive and unenjoyable, and honestly could have been done better with either reduced/smarter use of it, or near complete removal of it.If Blendo Games decides to come back to this universe, I'd really like a more fleshed out experience next time. I don't mind the linearity or the absurd-yet-serious tone, but there's just not enough here to justify your time or your money.

I found it to be quite captivating and once you finish it, there is still a lot to think about. I'd say this "game", just like Dear Esther, comes closer to being art than to being a game. So definitely not for everyone.

												Very high metascore... for what exactly? I loved Gravity Bone, and I'm glad this included a copy with the purchase... but the game engine crashed far too often for me to enjoy it, that, and the game is much shorter than Gravity Bone, with less interaction, and less puzzles. Get it on sale if you can, just to be able to play Gravity Bone (although you can get a copy of that for free on the internets) I *want* to recommend it, because it was still an interesting experience, but I can't in all honesty do that. (Sorry to the few folks I suggested buy this game)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Thirty Flights of Loving does not feel like a game. But understand, right now: this is not a failing. What is it then?As near as I can tell, Thirty Flights is a non-linear interactive story played out across several charmingly presented and deeply odd instances involving smuggling and espionage. The tale has it all: romance, excitement, Jeff Goldblum, ducks, mutes, illegal substances, and comradeship. It also has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. So, what does Thirty Flights of Loving does feel like?A bloody good time. You will play through it again and again - okay, at least twice - following the same path, but trying to figure out quite what just happened, and why, and how; and when exactly it ended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Ooh, a heist game that pays tribute to the films of Wong Kar-wai, tinted with the sensibilities of French New Wave, and is inspired by classic adventure games of yore! Sign me up!Thirty Flights of Loving doesn't even last the amount of time indicated in its title, but the experience is as powerful as a dozen bottles of downed prohibited hooch to the gut.Told through a series of jump cuts, you and your allies arrange a heist but -- as seen in the introduction -- it goes horribly wrong. Jump cuts send you back to an earlier time, then one less idyllic, then one utterly chaotic.Twists and turns develop -- was that a ********* person ******* in my ***? It is! And what about the **** at the end? Despite the game being on rails, the narrative is not. Wait, rails? That's right. The game, more of an interactive short film, is essentially you holding W to move from jump cut to jump cut, and occasionally pressing E to interact with an object. Do this often, I implore you!If you want to control a character that'll shootmens and look down at his 4K-textured hands and shout in desperate confusion, "What have I become?!" then this isn't the game for you. If you want to take a break from the usual games and follow along a neat little narrative, then strap yourself in for a ride.After all, it's just a quick heist -- in and out. What have you got to lose?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												My grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him "if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately." Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28 I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for having never done it, because this game gave me cancer anyways

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2013
												A very interesting experiment in first person non-linear storytelling. If you are interested in storytelling, how tales are told and put together, independent or small team games (just one man), or things that are unique I recommend it wholeheartedly. The game is also very film-like and film inspired, growing out of its influences to create a new original experiences. If you are looking for a fully fleshed and feature first person action or gaming experience then this is not it and you will be disappointed, but that is not the point of this game. Thirty Flights subverts the tropes of first person games intentionally to create a game that is different for each player depending on the baggage, or lack thereof, they bring with them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Thirty Flights of Loving is an interactive art piece, pure and simple. It's similar to "Dear Esther" in that there is no actual game play, however, the story is fun and it's visually appealing. The style reminds me of Mine Craft using that popular cubism style. The story was fun, kind of like a 70s hiest movie. If you jump right into it you may be a bit confused but a second play through will bring clarity, since the time line in the story is non-linear. Which brings my next point, also like "Dear Esther", the game play is relatively short. I'de say there is about fifteen to thirty minutes of game time. Over all, it was an enjoyable experience though.However, i have the same issue that i had with "Dear Ester". These games are great but they last a very short time. Also, they have virtually zero re-play value. Given that, i don't think i would have paid full price for either of them had i known this. Let's give some perspective...Dear Esther is 10$ with around a hour and a half of game time...Thirty Flights of Loving is 5$ with around twenty-two minutes of game time...a movie ticket is around 10$ and normally about two hours.These artistic game experiences are great but i would only recommend buying them on sale. Thirty Flights of Loving was on sale for just over a dollar, Dear Esther was on sale for around four dollars i think. Wait for the sales, but definitely buy them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This game is a very short exercise in creative and finely honed storytelling.  A lot of thought clearly went into its design.  In a short space of time, using very basic tools, Thirty Flights of Loving is able to make you think and feel more than much longer and more highly produced games.  The blocky LEGO-like characters while incredibly basic still manage to express emotion and lend the game its own unique style.  Due credit must be given for the finely honed way in which the game engages the player's imagination.  However, it's hard to shake the feeling that this is more of game programming student's project worthy of an 'A' grade than a fully realized game.  For $1.69, I found it worthy of my money and time if only for the fact that it got me thinking about game design and how to engage player imagination in a streamlined fashion.  I would not have appreciated this game as much if I had not played through a second time with the developer commentary.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Things you probably already know about the game from other reviews:- It's 10 minutes long. Max. - It is confusing.- Whether the game even has a story (linear or otherwise) is up for debate- If you pay $5 for it, you will be angry.Now, why do critics like this? Because the game has an incredibly interesting style, and makes us of some wonderful effects I've never seen before (interactive jump-cuts, soft-bloom floating people, Guy Ritchie-style job descriptions in physical space, etc.) If I paid two bucks for this (which it is right now), I would be okay. If it were even 10 minutes longer, I'd be okay with $5. Hell, just add any sense of choice at all (multiple endings, non-objective-related interactivity) and sure, I'd still be alright with $5. As it stands, though, there's just not a lot here. This doesn't feel like a game. It feels like a demo.Oh, and if you want two things in the same vein that ARE worth it, Gravity Bone is free on the developer's website, and JazzPunk is a full game with a similar aesthetic.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Spoiler free review:It's a challenge to describe this game without giving it away. It plays more like an interactive short film than anything. The story is told in anachronic order with sudden cutwaways and relies on the scenery and subtle (and not so subtle) cues to tell the player what's happening.It's short and sweet, and a great achievement in the medium.Do I recommend this? Yes and no. A very niche sector of gamers would like this. The player character does very little and the lack of action may rub some people the wrong way (well except maybe for Gravity Bone, the free to play prequel included in this release, which has some action).But if you enjoy a good piece of fiction and like to piece togheter the events of the game and you don't mind the experience being about ten minutes short, by all means buy this thing!On a personal note, I loved it and played it a few times with the developer commentary to gain a better insight of it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												This is an experimental, highly linear game which sees you only walking through scripted events to move the disjointed narrative (which leaves a lot to the player's imagination to discover) forward. Think of it as an interactive, yet not-so-intruiging short Pulp Fiction kind of story. The entire experience takes about 10 minutes and there's a developer commentary option too which is text-based and is mostly about the game creator himself than the game but some of the facts are cool to read. The game itself has its moments and it gets pretty intense towards the end.As an added bonus, the developer's previous game, Gravity Bone is also included in the package and can be played from the main menu. The irony here is that the main gem of this package is indeed the older one. Gravity bone is more interactive and has a much less bizarre narrative than 30 Flights of Loving. I guess this is really for the niche audience who'd like to have this kind of experience. I personally enjoyed it but exhausted every single aspect of it in less than 2 hours. If you want gameplay, stay away.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 23, 2013
												Thirty Flights of Loving is a game that, just like To the Moon and Kentucky Route Zero, proves how powerful the interactive medium of video games can be in telling a story. Played from a first-person view, there is virtually no traditional gameplay, aside from being able to interact with the environment and explore its nooks and crannies. The soundtrack and the sound design are great, as well as its graphical presentation. The blocky characters, the usage of color, and the varied environments all mesh together into a game that looks quite unlike any other.But yes, there is nothing the player really does in the game, at least, not in the traditional sense. The real reason to play this game is for its story and, more specifically, the way the game presents its story. By employing the mechanics of film editing and cutting freely between events and scenes without any sort of input from the player, Thirty Flights of Loving spins the classic yarn of a heist gone horribly wrong in a wholly unique way. Its non-linearity and hectic pace is a refreshing change from the banality of most video game narratives, and the player truly has to work in order to understand everything that's happening. While the game can be completed in fifteen minutes or so, the scope and depth of the story told is one that far exceeds its actual runtime. Multiple playthroughs are not only necessary but also inevitable.Thirty Flights of Loving is certainly not for everyone. Many players have expressed outrage or frustration at the fact that the "game" isn't really much of one at all. Brendon Chung, the creator of the game, has himself described it as "an interactive short story". Ultimately, it does not matter. Thirty Filghts of Loving is a very important game, because it makes a legitimate attempt to tap into the vast potential for video games as a narrative medium. If that sounds at all interesting to you, go play Thirty Flights of Loving. It's an experience that you won't soon forget.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												Thirty Flights of Loving is the best answer to the question "How much narrative can you fit into a 15 minutes time frame?".You'll spend those 15 minutes as an unnamed member of a team preparing an heist and excaping from it.Also included, once you complete the game, is the first game "Gravity Bone" where you play as a spy in two different missions.PROS:-charming graphics and art style-top notch soundtrack-extremely good story told in a condensed and non-linear way-quirky sense of humour-"Gravity Bone" is just as good and gives you 15 more minutes of gameplayCONS:-very short and linear-while the soundtrack is very nice the sounds (guns, vehicles etc..) are unimpressive


Thirty Flights of Loving 
A Screenshot of Thirty Flights of Loving
By: stranger1982




The fact that, once it was over, I wished it'd have been longer, a full game, is a testament to the game's top notch narrative. But perhaps its power truly lies in how well it tells a story and engages you as a player in such a short time.The game is indeed very short, linear and with little replay value but it'd be experienced at least once as a token of great storytelling: I agree the full price is too much for what it offers but it's absolutely worth it when on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Ooh, a heist game that pays tribute to the films of Wong Kar-wai, tinted with the sensibilities of French New Wave, and is inspired by classic adventure games of yore! Sign me up!Thirty Flights of Loving doesn't even last the amount of time indicated in its title, but the experience is as powerful as a dozen bottles of downed prohibited hooch to the gut.Told through a series of jump cuts, you and your allies arrange a heist but -- as seen in the introduction -- it goes horribly wrong. Jump cuts send you back to an earlier time, then one less idyllic, then one utterly chaotic.Twists and turns develop -- was that a ********* person ******* in my ***? It is! And what about the **** at the end? Despite the game being on rails, the narrative is not. Wait, rails? That's right. The game, more of an interactive short film, is essentially you holding W to move from jump cut to jump cut, and occasionally pressing E to interact with an object. Do this often, I implore you!If you want to control a character that'll shootmens and look down at his 4K-textured hands and shout in desperate confusion, "What have I become?!" then this isn't the game for you. If you want to take a break from the usual games and follow along a neat little narrative, then strap yourself in for a ride.After all, it's just a quick heist -- in and out. What have you got to lose?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22
Product received for free
												I'm all for games being as long as they need to be. Not every game needs to be a a 10 hour epic or 50+ hour open world game. A 2 hour game can sometimes tell a great story just as well and lends itself to tight and focused gameplay.With this game I thought I was in some sort of extended flashback introduction the whole time. When I got to the end I thought that the intro had drug on a little too long and behaps spoiled its plot a little too much, but no, what I thought was a transition to the start of the proper game was the end of the game entirely. Even when I took my time turning around and poking into dark empty corners the whole 'experince' took me less than 30 minutes. I was left feeling like I had played a demo. There are short games and there are artistic experments that should fall under freeware. This, in my mind, falls into the latter.

												My grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him "if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately." Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28 I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for having never done it, because this game gave me cancer anyways

												I understand why some feel cheated by this game, but I didn't at all. It's a genuinely brilliant demonstration of how you can use snappy editing in games to tell a story that is thrilling, violent, funny, romantic, tense, wistful and tragic - and somehow manage all of that in ten minutes. I've gone back to it (and Gravity Bone) several times, just marvelling at all the fabulous little touches.Worried about the price? Fine: wishlist it, wait till it's on sale, you'll pay the price of a cup of coffee for something far more memorable.

VERDICT Wait for sale (6.5/10)Completion Time: 10-20 minutesBottom Line: "A virtual picturebook"PROS+Engaging and Unique+Storytelling like never beforeCONS-Very very shortREVIEWAfter having completed this game multiple times now, I am left speechless. This is an incredibly engaging and unique experience that is simply incomparable to anything else out there. There is no way for me to tell you anything about the game without spoiling it. I would even advise against watching the trailer. What I will say is that this game is purely about story, and not about gameplay. Consider it a virtual picture book of sorts. That being said, this game is only 10 minutes long. You heard correctly. Ten minutes. If you include the second campaign in the package (which was the first project by this studio) you have a total of around 20 minutes. So if you are going to buy the game, get it on sale for a couple dollars. In my humble opinion, the money is well worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												There seems to be a growing trend among the gaming industry about making the big titles as flashy as a Hollywood blockbuster helmed by Michael Bay.  It's all about the pretty skyboxes and particle effects.  Story and character have been given the boot in lieu of a more visually appealing game.  Well this game, as short as it is, is the complete opposite of what the triple A gaming industry is doing as it proves that with only a few visual cues and some basic animation a story can form all on its own.That has always been the beauty of gaming, the capacity of story-telling within a medium and allowing the player to use his imagination to fill in the gaps.  A hearty recommendation for anyone.  Although I would say to wait for the price to drop during a sale, as the length of the game may put many people off.

												I wouldn't really call this a game in the literal sense, despite having some game elements. But rather consider it more as an artistic piece accompanied by a great story. The mixed reviews certainly show the confusion behind this, as it really does come down to how one interprets this. If you have expectations on what this is, throw them out the window before getting this. In many ways this is ahead of it's time, fusing artistic expression as an interactive piece. I hope to see more of this style on Steam in future.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												So, what is this game? It's basically 15 minutes of story time, in which the author(s) weaves together a quick series of flash shots together. The minimalistic method is interesting, and entertaining enough for a one-time playthrough.  It's not great by any stretch of the imagination, though. The story given does not provide much literary merit, and is not nearly long enough to provide substantial "proof" for its concept. All it appears to be is a vehicle to demonstrate the potential of a unique storytelling concept to the video game medium. It works, but I would have liked an expansion on this idea beyond a 15-minute demo reel. Your impact as a player is nonexistent. There are no choices to be made. Failure is impossible. Your sole purpose is to tag along for the ride and see what Thirty Flights of Loving has to show you. At this point, there is no reason why this shouldn't be a short film instead, which is a perfect medium to make itself right at home. Is it art? Yes. But is it a game? No.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Thirty Flights of Loving does not feel like a game. But understand, right now: this is not a failing. What is it then?As near as I can tell, Thirty Flights is a non-linear interactive story played out across several charmingly presented and deeply odd instances involving smuggling and espionage. The tale has it all: romance, excitement, Jeff Goldblum, ducks, mutes, illegal substances, and comradeship. It also has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. So, what does Thirty Flights of Loving does feel like?A bloody good time. You will play through it again and again - okay, at least twice - following the same path, but trying to figure out quite what just happened, and why, and how; and when exactly it ended.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
SPOILER ALERT!!!I didn't really understand the game until I read the excellent explanation below from Reddit."Says Jazzputin:Here's what I think went down.1. You are a thief. You meet with two other master thieves, Anita and Borges, who have planned a heist. You proceed to fly to a building at which the robbery takes place. [SHOWN]2. You spend a day in the hotel planning/waiting for the heist (this the part where you see Anita throwing orange peels off the building). [SHOWN]3. As part of the heist you must pose as party guests, so you attend a party on the roof and everyone gets drunk. [SHOWN]4. You hook up with Anita (this is where things start to go wrong in the story). [SHOWN]5. You and Anita wake up in a hungover stupor; Borges is missing. [NOT SHOWN]6. Because the whole gang got drunk and woke up hungover and not ready for the heist, the heist is not set up properly and goes terribly wrong. Borges and Anita are both seriously injured. [NOT SHOWN]7. You and Borges escape through a mall/airport sort of place. [SHOWN] Anita manages to escape on her own somehow, despite her injuries. [NOT SHOWN]8. You and Borges, still escaping, face a standoff with police. [NOT SHOWN]9. During the standoff, Anita arrives in a getaway car, you get in and a chase ensues. [NOT SHOWN]10. The chase becomes deadly once Borges starts shooting at the police. At this moment the seriousness of the situation hits you; you realize you will not make it out of this. At this moment you have a fantasy: you realize you are in love with Anita, and you fantasize how nice it would be if you, her and Borges could live a simpler life if you just got away (the motorcycle scene). [SHOWN]11. In real life your car approaches a head-on collision with a semi, you can hear/see the semi in your dream and you come back to reality, and your car collides head-on with the semi. [SHOWN]I think the very end is ambiguous on purpose; it's not clear whether you survived the crash or died. The lobby you find yourself at the end could be a metaphor for the afterlife, or an extended life-flashing-before-your-eyes time for your character where he views previous parts of his life like museum exhibits."

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												There seems to be a growing trend among the gaming industry about making the big titles as flashy as a Hollywood blockbuster helmed by Michael Bay.  It's all about the pretty skyboxes and particle effects.  Story and character have been given the boot in lieu of a more visually appealing game.  Well this game, as short as it is, is the complete opposite of what the triple A gaming industry is doing as it proves that with only a few visual cues and some basic animation a story can form all on its own.That has always been the beauty of gaming, the capacity of story-telling within a medium and allowing the player to use his imagination to fill in the gaps.  A hearty recommendation for anyone.  Although I would say to wait for the price to drop during a sale, as the length of the game may put many people off.

Posted: September 29, 2014
												I wouldn't really call this a game in the literal sense, despite having some game elements. But rather consider it more as an artistic piece accompanied by a great story. The mixed reviews certainly show the confusion behind this, as it really does come down to how one interprets this. If you have expectations on what this is, throw them out the window before getting this. In many ways this is ahead of it's time, fusing artistic expression as an interactive piece. I hope to see more of this style on Steam in future.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												So, what is this game? It's basically 15 minutes of story time, in which the author(s) weaves together a quick series of flash shots together. The minimalistic method is interesting, and entertaining enough for a one-time playthrough.  It's not great by any stretch of the imagination, though. The story given does not provide much literary merit, and is not nearly long enough to provide substantial "proof" for its concept. All it appears to be is a vehicle to demonstrate the potential of a unique storytelling concept to the video game medium. It works, but I would have liked an expansion on this idea beyond a 15-minute demo reel. Your impact as a player is nonexistent. There are no choices to be made. Failure is impossible. Your sole purpose is to tag along for the ride and see what Thirty Flights of Loving has to show you. At this point, there is no reason why this shouldn't be a short film instead, which is a perfect medium to make itself right at home. Is it art? Yes. But is it a game? No.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Thirty Flights of Game Design:I you are into more modern games that force-feed you story, you probably won't like this game. It takes a quite different approach by explaining the plot through small chunks of information, forcing the player to piece together the events that happen. The result of this is a confusing and interesting series of small levels that  continue the plot. This game is meant to be a ride more than a game I would say, though there are game elements involved through small objectives or the possibility of death.For five dollars, this game is an interesting experience. I wasn't sure what to think when I beat it, but I liked that feeling. All I can say is that if you are a fan of interesting game design, you must play this game. If not, meh, I enjoyed it a lot. I think it's worth it.

												It's really hard to recommend this game. I'm not saying I think it's bad (I think it's brilliant), I'm saying that it seems like it's directed at an extremely small audience. I think most will see this as a rushed, incomplete game, but others will likely view it as an extremely interesting look at narrative in video games. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2013
												A very interesting experiment in first person non-linear storytelling. If you are interested in storytelling, how tales are told and put together, independent or small team games (just one man), or things that are unique I recommend it wholeheartedly. The game is also very film-like and film inspired, growing out of its influences to create a new original experiences. If you are looking for a fully fleshed and feature first person action or gaming experience then this is not it and you will be disappointed, but that is not the point of this game. Thirty Flights subverts the tropes of first person games intentionally to create a game that is different for each player depending on the baggage, or lack thereof, they bring with them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Originally an early prototype for Blendo Games’s Gravity Bone, TFOL is difficult to classify within traditional gaming genres. Is it an adventure game, an action game, an art game, or an elegiac love poem? Well, it’s all of these and none. 30 Flights is an indie gamer's indie game. It occupies the same experimental vein as Proteus, The Path, and Journey. I know that may scare some of you off, but it shouldn’t. TFOL is basically a slick crime caper gone awry. Like Reservoir Dogs? You’ll probably enjoy this.As one comes to expect from indie indies, TFOL features simple graphics, quirky humor, an innovative yet enigmatic narrative structure, and great music. Despite its age, the Quake 2 engine has never looked this good. The blocky retro-visual style is utterly charming: think Minecraft meets No One Lives Forever.Thirty Flights of Loving focuses its sharp satirical lens on the over-the-top cinematism rife in video games and their tendency to imitate big-budget Hollywood Action movies. But it is also a powerful and moving homage to the stylish, discontinuous narration of French New Wave films. The game has often been compared to the work of Tarantino, but both the plot and razor sharp editing owes more to the formal innovations of Jean-Luc Godard's seminal film, A bout de souffle. Much of the central game experience involves trying to piece together its intricately crafted story. Temporal and spatial leaps await the player at every turn. Brendon Chung has a knack for capturing the gritty underworld vernacular that our anti-heroes inhabit. Interspersed throughout the game are moments of transcendent beauty. In one, Anita sits peeling oranges overlooking her vast apartment courtyard. The sound is particularly used to great effect here, realistically capturing the nocturnal soundscape of a large urban metropolis. In the climactic gunfight, the action recalls the poetic rhythm of Koyaanisqatsi and Baraka. Without relying on dialogue text, voiceover narration, or UI, Brendon Chung manages to convey an entire world and story through the environment.To what degree any of this makes sense depends on the player’s perception. What exactly went down at Cugat airfield? Who is Winston Borges (a.k.a. Mo Golden, Moco Rococo, The Big Pai-Goo)? Is Bernoulli’s Principle the key to unlocking this puzzle? These are just some of the many questions you’ll ask yourself in 30 Flights of Loving.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine  PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game Thirty Flights of Loving is a game developed by Blendo Games. The game forms part of the Citizen Abel series which also has a prequel known as Gravity Bone which is also include in the gameThe game is extremely short, I completed everything the game had to offer in under 30 minutes and that for me is kind of ridiculous. I am not going to mention anything of the story because if I did I would tell you not to buy this game. The game is surprisingly developed on the Quake II and it shows as the game is horribly optimsed for modern systems, expect crashes if you want to play the game at 1920x1080There are also some sound issues and graphical glitches which hinder the game. Honestly, this game should have been offered for free as what Blendo Games did for Gravity Bone. Honestly, the game is extremely short and I discovered what the game had to offer in a relatively short time. This includes finishing Thirty Flights of Loving, Gravity Bone and playing Thirty Flights of Loving with its developer commentaryHonestly, even for the price the game is offering now, I wouldn't recommend it at all. Wait until it's dirt cheap (which is what I had done) or (although I do not condone it) pirate it and just see what the game has to offerOtherwise don't bother... RECOMMENDED :)

content:
Posted: October 17, 2013
VERDICT Wait for sale (6.5/10)Completion Time: 10-20 minutesBottom Line: "A virtual picturebook"PROS+Engaging and Unique+Storytelling like never beforeCONS-Very very shortREVIEWAfter having completed this game multiple times now, I am left speechless. This is an incredibly engaging and unique experience that is simply incomparable to anything else out there. There is no way for me to tell you anything about the game without spoiling it. I would even advise against watching the trailer. What I will say is that this game is purely about story, and not about gameplay. Consider it a virtual picture book of sorts. That being said, this game is only 10 minutes long. You heard correctly. Ten minutes. If you include the second campaign in the package (which was the first project by this studio) you have a total of around 20 minutes. So if you are going to buy the game, get it on sale for a couple dollars. In my humble opinion, the money is well worth it.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												I understand why some feel cheated by this game, but I didn't at all. It's a genuinely brilliant demonstration of how you can use snappy editing in games to tell a story that is thrilling, violent, funny, romantic, tense, wistful and tragic - and somehow manage all of that in ten minutes. I've gone back to it (and Gravity Bone) several times, just marvelling at all the fabulous little touches.Worried about the price? Fine: wishlist it, wait till it's on sale, you'll pay the price of a cup of coffee for something far more memorable.

												I find Thirty Flights of Loving very difficult to recommend. On the one hand, it's a finely crafted story and well stylised experience. On the other hand, it's very short. Like - 5 minutes kinda sort. Where the idea falls down is that it sacrifices gameplay for artistic expression. However, it does come with Gravity Bone, which is more of a game. That too could have been expanded upon, with different objectives per mission. It's a boiling broth of potential that just leaves you with a taste of faceless brievity. If it's on sale (maybe a quid), then pick it up.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												After playing the ~20 minute long game, you're given the option to replay with developer commentary. This mode takes you from scene to scene, but allows you to step back and look at how the game is constructed, on both a technical and storytelling level. You can noclip around each scene to look around, and interact with text bubbles that highlight notable design decisions. I enjoyed the game, but I even more enjoyed digging into how the game was made.Blendo is a smart indie dev, getting to look into his design process was well worth $5 for me.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Wouldn't say this game is meant to be fun or a "game" in the traditional sense.  There's no open world, no dialog trees, and no dialog - plain and and simple..  It's short story told with narrative concision.A lot of the TFoL's story is subtley told through the environment or "mise en scene".  Even the disjointed narrative can slowly be pieced back into a chronological order when you assess your surroundings.  There's a difference between a game that smash-cuts to the past with an accompanying "3 days prior..." intertitle and one that lets the viewer/interactee figure it out on their own.The director's commentary is also a great addition for anyone interested in the developers design choices.  Same goes for the additional "prequel" content for anyone who wants flesh-out the TFoL universe.If you're still on the fence, buy when in a bundle or sale and remember to utilize the steam refund policy.

												I'm all for games being as long as they need to be. Not every game needs to be a a 10 hour epic or 50+ hour open world game. A 2 hour game can sometimes tell a great story just as well and lends itself to tight and focused gameplay.With this game I thought I was in some sort of extended flashback introduction the whole time. Even when I took my time turning around and poking into dark empty corners the whole 'experince' took me less than 30 minutes. I was left feeling like I had played a demo. There are short games and there are artistic experments that should fall under freeware. This, in my mind, falls into the latter.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
A disappointing follow-up.I was a really big fan of Gravity Bone, and so I bought this game even though I knew it would be short. However, while the length did not disappoint,the game did. Compared to Gravity Bone, Thirty Flights Of Loving focuses more on trying to tell a story and ends up jumping around a lot in time and space and features more interactions with non-player characters. Unlike Gravity Bone, which had at least a few jumping puzzles, there is really no challenge at all to the game. The story also feels much less player-driven: as I mentioned before, it jumps around a lot in time instead of allowing the player to explore and experience the game at their own pace.Not worth $5.If you haven't played Gravity Bone, the original game, I implore you to check it out. It's a really cool, mysterious game that does a lot in a short time. And it's free to download at the Blendo Games website.

												Hard Cut: The GameReal talk though, this is a very short game that kinda serves more as an exercise in narrative more than anything else. In most games, story moments are broken up by gameplay and bosses, maybe just a level with some scenery. There is none of that here; You prep for a mission and then the games skips to the end before you even realize it. It does flashbacks, stylized shots, and vague narrative the same way Tarantino does movies, minus dialogue of course. If you're a connesuir of games or enjoy experimental storytelling, this is right up your alley. Otherwise, it's something to kill 10-12 minutes.

												My grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him "if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately." Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28 I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for having never done it, because this game gave me cancer anyways

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Thirty Flights of Loving, as well as the accompaying Gravity Bone, aren't so much what I'd call video games, strictly speaking. Rather, they are interactive narratives, focusing not so much on the common aspects of gameplay and agency, and instead on the tools of exploration only really available to the gaming medium in order to tell their stories. A lot is left to the player's imagination, but there's just enough context to present something cogent and engaging. Aesthetically, I love this, with both its references to old-school espionage films and reliance on simple modular design. I recommend this strictly to experience this type of storytelling.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19
												I really liked the presentation and pacing of this game. The way the narrative is presented really worked for me. The soundtrack cues come in perfectly. The story is cute as well. I don't get the emotional impact some writers talk about, but thats more of a my problem than it is the game's problem. Stories resonate for each of us differently, and maybe if I were in different circumstances it might have knocked a feeling or two loose. Who knows. I did enjoy it's sense of whimsy and adventure.There are lots of great little details if you care to look for them. I did care, and played through two times, then another time with the commentary. One of the nice things about short, dense games is that the investment time is low and I can easily explore them again and see new things. In larger games I get choice paralysis sometimes, where my desire to experience every bit causes me to get distracted when something is actually happening but oh no there was that hallway back there I didnt look in what if I missed some sick loots...The previus game in the series, Gravity Bone is included. While it's free from Blendogames.com, having it within the same package but as the 3rd option under the "Career" menu invited me to play it last and in succession. I did and appreciated the design choices re: failure states in Thirty Flights even more. I found it interesting to compare and contrast the previous work so quickly after completing the successor. Sorta like binge watching a movie series.This game is lovely and I recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 21
												I probably spent too much time on this game, but I wanted to look at every detail. I played it once through, then played it with the developer commentary, and then played Gravity Bone. I don't really understand why everyone is so upset with it being short. After the developer commentary, I understand it a great deal more and appreciate it. This game was originally scrapped because it wasn't working out, and the developer knew that and even points out a bunch of the flaws and explains why he did what he did. It was only a prototype and was brought back to life to help a kickstarter. Nothing wrong with that. No, it wasn't game of the year material. But it was fun for what it was. I also enjoyed Gravity Bone. Perception is largely based in expectation. I wouldn't pay too much for it, but if you're a fan of indie games and interested in how they're made, I'd recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 13
												As someone who loved the wackiness of Gravity Bone, Thirty Flights was just a disappointment to me. It is still incredibly short, being maybe 15 minutes long... and the plot. Well I'm not even sure what the plot was, beyond being vaguely spy themed and involving a love interest. It just felt like it was missing a few extra key details that would take the plot from "I don't know what happened" to "I'm not certain what happened, but I have a few strong theories and an overall idea". It didn't seem to understand the difference between "up for intepretation" and just being vague and confusing. There's not a great deal of repay value beyond looking for plot details you may have missed.I thought I was in for a treat, but I got something with less charm than Gravity Bone, and despite being free no real extra length or production value.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21
												I probably spent too much time on this game, but I wanted to look at every detail. I played it once through, then played it with the developer commentary, and then played Gravity Bone. I don't really understand why everyone is so upset with it being short. After the developer commentary, I understand it a great deal more and appreciate it. This game was originally scrapped because it wasn't working out, and the developer knew that and even points out a bunch of the flaws and explains why he did what he did. It was only a prototype and was brought back to life to help a kickstarter. Nothing wrong with that. No, it wasn't game of the year material. But it was fun for what it was. I also enjoyed Gravity Bone. Perception is largely based in expectation. I wouldn't pay too much for it, but if you're a fan of indie games and interested in how they're made, I'd recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 14
												I'm gonna say right off the bat, although I enjoy and recommend this game, I got it in a humble bundle and I'd be REALLY hard-pressed to say it's worth the asking 5$.  That being said; this game is less a "walking simulator" and more of a short film in the form of a game.  This feels like a lucid dream, and absolute trip.  And that in and of itself is what makes it a worthwhile story.  Although it's very hard to say anything without spoiling it, I'd say the fun "game" aspect is really just trying to figure out what the hell it's about.  Have you ever watched a bizarre psychological thriller and wondered throughout the film "wtf is this even supposed to be about?!?!" This game essentially is like that, but is a bit less patient and doesn't really keep you guessing that long.  Overall I did highly enjoy it, even if my steam log literally says "13 minutes played."  It is, simply put, a quality story in a trippy environment.  The ending is abrupt however, and unless you got it on sale or in a bundle, I can't imagine not being disappointed if I spent 5$.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16
												I loved Gravity Bone, this didn't do the same for me.While I am usually all for a game being as long as it needs, this game is too short. I don't think it properly tells its story within the 5 mins it takes to complete (longer including replaying it due to crashes) and would benefit from being longer. All it manages to tell is a shell of a story, the elevator pitch of a story, but not a story itself.As for the crashing, how in the world can a game based upon the quake engine which is generally stable crash so often? The game is 5 mins long and has no gameplay outside of walking, no choices to be made outside of small insignificant enviornoment interactions, I can understand that bugs occasionally happen, but I am not the only one reporting issues. Its not like this game will have tens of thausands of lines of code on top of what the game engine provides, how is it not stable, after being on the market for this long?Funnily enough when I got to the end I thought it was doing a fake ending, little did I know that was literally it.I got this game with the Humble Freedom Bundle.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24
20 minutesThat's all it takes to beat this game. There are two "stories" you can play where both are you running around doing nothing. The game is a little like telltale games except the fact that you don't do anything of signifigance in this game but running around. It shows that the developer has put love into this game and spend his time with it but it is really nothing great. The music is half tom and jerry and half ruining my ears. The artstyle is clunky which is fine but i wouldn't compliment it. and the gameplay is just running around pressing E once in a while and that's it. There really isn't alot to this game and you're probably better off watching some show for 20 minutes. I did find the game a little fun playing but with such a high price and so little and boring gameplay is it not worth it at all. If there were added some more story and maybe improved the gameplay could it be closer to worth it but even then would it probably not be near worth the 5 bucks.

content:
Posted: February 25
												GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: 39% YES / 61% NOGOODVisual style is clean and inviting.Soundtrack is stellar and adds to the campy spy vibe they're going for.NEUTRALThe story is unfortunately spastic and uninteresting, which really untangles this experience. I can see what they're going for, but too often does it jump around haphazardly and, if you look at the story overall, it's not very inventive. It's incredibly run-of-the mill, snack-sized spy tales.BADControls feel bad which, won't be a problem for most of the game since you barely have agency, but WILL matter if you attempt Gravity Bone where first person platforming is required. If you're wondering what it feels like to have a 9 minute game grind to a sudden halt, you'll find it at the flag poles.Quite frankly there just isn't much for you to do. In fact there's barely a need for the player to be there. Beyond buying this to support the developer, I honestly don't think any player will have any meaningful experience outside of just watching someone play this through a video site.SUMMARYMore art than an actual game, I just can't recommend people pay for this if they're wanting to PLAY a game. Absolutely buy this if you're wanting to support the dev and you liked the story after watching a video, but I doubt you'd have any different experiences playing this yourself.
